title: Dow drops 500 points in afternoon trade, stocks head for first back-to-back weekly loss since September; 'Increasingly, it looks like we're going to go into a recession,' says TCW's Brivanlou
text:
* Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA shed 522 points, or 1.6%, to to trade at 32,677.64, slightly above the session's low of 32,654.59.

* The S&P 500 SPX fell 65 points, or 1.7%, to about 3,829.

* Nasdaq Composite COMP slid almost 158 points, or 1.5%, to around 10,651.

On Thursday, the Dow industrials tumbled 2.3%, its biggest daily drop since Sept. 13. The S&P 500 fell 2.5% and the Nasdaq Composite sank 3.2%. All three indexes Friday were on track to book back-to-back weekly losses for the first time since the week ended Sept. 30.

Need to Know: Given up on Wall Street? Here's how stocks could rally 20% next year, says veteran analyst

What's driving markets?

U.S. stocks were down Friday and heading for weekly losses as investors digested a flurry of interest-rate hikes from global central banks and more discouraging signs about the U.S. economy and spending power of the consumer.

The Federal Reserve sent stocks down after on Wednesday, delivering a 50 basis point rate hike and indicating interest rates could remain above 5% into 2024.

"The market is coming to terms" with the Fed's hawkish messaging, said Iman Brivanlou, head of income equities at TCW Group, in a phone interview Friday. "Increasingly, it looks like we're going to go into a recession."

Read: Why the consumer is 'critical' for investors to watch in 2023 as bear market 'not yet complete'

Brivanlou said he is defensively positioned, preferring areas such as healthcare and utilities, but wary of consumer staples, as the sector appears relatively expensive compared with other defensive parts of the equities market.

Nearly all off the S&P 500's sectors are on track to finish the week in the red, with the exception of energy. Still, energy stocks were trading down Friday as oil prices CL.1 fell to around $74 a barrel.

Markets appeared to be waking up to the notion that the Fed won't be pivoting back to interest-rate cuts any time soon, said Paul Nolte, portfolio manager at Kingsview Asset Management.

"Powell has been very consistent with his message to the markets: We're going to keep raising rates. We're on this path. We might do it more slowly but we're not going to stop and pivot," Nolte said. "It's just taking the market a while to get comfortable with this."

Jeffrey Kleintop, chief global investment strategist at Charles Schwab & Co, said the market "bought the rumor" of a decrease in the size of Fed rate hikes from 75 basis points to 50 basis points, and now it's "selling the news," because it's coming with more signs of recession.

Read: Stocks are plunging because the Fed 'cannot lose the battle' on inflation`

In economic data released Friday, the S&P Global "flash" U.S. services sector index showed business conditions eroded again in December. Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs Group GS is planning to lay off as many as 4,000 people, Semafor reportedFriday, citing people familiar with the matter.

The New York Fed's John Williams said Friday thatinterest rates need to top the inflation rateto get prices under control, saying that pricing pressures are still "stubbornly high," and that he expects rates will hold above 5% next year. Outside the U.S., the European Central Bank was among the central banks that hiked rates this week.

As the trading week wraps up, a flurry of expiring equity options and futures contracts could also make for a volatile Friday session.

Single-stock movers

* Meta Platforms Inc. META shares were up 3.2% Friday, helping to bolster the Nasdaq as analysts cheered the company's cost-cutting efforts.

* Several real-estate investment Trusts focused on corporate properties and logistics centers were under pressure on Friday, including Prologis Inc. PLD , Invitation Homes Inc. INVH, Equity Residential EQR, Digital Realty Trust DLRand SL Green Realty Corp. SLG.
